title: 110_hr4833
content: The Act is titled the "Santa Fe Quadricentennial Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the commemoration. The Congress finds that Santa Fe, New Mexico, with its rich history dating back to native occupation, was elevated to a capital city in 1610. The Palace of the Governors, built in the early 17th century, is the oldest continuously used public building in the United States. La Fiesta de Santa Fe, a cultural celebration, commemorates the resettlement of Santa Fe in 1692. Santa Fe served as a hub for people and goods traveling along historically important trails. Santa Fe served as a hub for traders and travelers on the Santa Fe Trail, boosting the American Midwest's economy during the early 19th century. Today, Santa Fe is a multicultural city known for its art market and attracts tourists, artists, and writers year-round. New Mexico is home to the oldest continuously inhabited indigenous communities in North America. The oldest continuously inhabited indigenous communities in North America are found in New Mexico, including Acoma Pueblo, Navajo Chapters, Pueblos, Apache Tribes, and more. Many native communities disappeared or were relocated after European contact. The Pueblo Revolt of 1680 was a significant event where the Pueblo people expelled Spanish colonists from New Mexico. The Santa Fe area has long attracted tourists, artists, and writers. Governor Lew Wallace wrote part of Ben Hur in the Palace of the Governors. A commemorative coin will foster an understanding of New Mexico's history and culture. The commemorative coin will have specific specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the quadricentennial of the City of Santa Fe, New Mexico. The coins will have specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins will be legal tender. Coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items and the gold and silver for the coins will be acquired domestically. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize the settlement of Santa Fe, New Mexico, the oldest capital city in the United States. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2010", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single United States Mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2010. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act include a surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin and $10 per coin for the $1 coin. Surcharges received will be split with 50% going to the Santa Fe 400th Anniversary Committee to support programs promoting the understanding of Santa Fe's legacies, and the other 50% going to the Secretary of the Interior for preserving missions. The Santa Fe 400th Anniversary Committee aims to sustain the mission of preserving Santa Fe, enhance national and international programs, improve infrastructure and archaeological research, and conduct programs supporting the quadricentennial. The Committee and the Secretary of the Interior will be audited as per section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code.
